text:
Couple things:
• If this were a problem, various overlays (e.g. tree-based) are simple solutions. Anna has a DHT under the covers that could support that naturally.
• The use of lattices allows updates to be smaller — this is in the paper.

elements.text: Couple things:
If this were a problem, various overlays (e.g. tree-based) are simple solutions. Anna has a DHT under the covers that could support that naturally.
The use of lattices allows updates to be smaller — this is in the paper.

text: No, that’s not required. It’s consistency-level dependent, but LWW is (as in most systems) pretty wildly inconsistent and depends on local clocks. For stronger levels like causal, the lattice composition can carry local clocks around — i.e. vector clocks or Lamport clocks.

elements.text: No, that’s not required. It’s consistency-level dependent, but LWW is (as in most systems) pretty wildly inconsistent and depends on local clocks. For stronger levels like causal, the lattice composition can carry local clocks around — i.e. vector clocks or Lamport clocks.

text: How "efficient" are the lattice-based approaches in terms of 1) metadata that you have to store (for ex for causal consistency, most of the challenges in existing system is addressing metadata growth) 2) how fine-grained they are with what they describe as "causally related".

elements.text: How "efficient" are the lattice-based approaches in terms of 1) metadata that you have to store (for ex for causal consistency, most of the challenges in existing system is addressing metadata growth) 2) how fine-grained they are with what they describe as "causally related".

text: That’s a bit flip, I know. But we’ve done vector clocks and dependency graphs; both are lattices and they have tradeoffs depending on workload. I don’t think it’s hard to cast typical causal metadata into lattice structures.

elements.text: That’s a bit flip, I know. But we’ve done vector clocks and dependency graphs; both are lattices and they have tradeoffs depending on workload. I don’t think it’s hard to cast typical causal metadata into lattice structures.

text:
```cloud = CloudburstClient(ADDRESS, MY_IP)
cloud.register(lambda x: x ** 2, 'square')
cloud.register(lambda x: x + 1, 'increment')
cloud.register_dag(['increment', 'square'])

cloud.call_dag({'incr': 1})
>>> 4```
Where is the typo?

text:
```cloud = CloudburstClient(ADDRESS, MY_IP)
cloud.register(lambda x: x ** 2, 'square')
cloud.register(lambda x: x + 1, 'increment')
cloud.register_dag('composition', ['increment', 'square'])

cloud.call_dag('composition', {'increment': 1})
>>> 4```
This is the correct version I believe.

elements.text:
cloud = CloudburstClient(ADDRESS, MY_IP)
cloud.register(lambda x: x ** 2, 'square')
cloud.register(lambda x: x + 1, 'increment')
cloud.register_dag('composition', ['increment', 'square'])

cloud.call_dag('composition', {'increment': 1})
>>> 4
This is the correct version I believe.

text: Great question Natacha! Mencius attempts to eliminate the leader bottleneck, but doesn't look at eliminating other bottlenecks. Unfortunately, when you eliminate one bottleneck, another arises, so it's important to eliminate them all. In our paper, we have a whole section on compartmentalizing Mencius if anyone is looking for more information on that: <https://mwhittaker.github.io/publications/compartmentalized_consensus.pdf>

elements.text: Great question Natacha! Mencius attempts to eliminate the leader bottleneck, but doesn't look at eliminating other bottlenecks. Unfortunately, when you eliminate one bottleneck, another arises, so it's important to eliminate them all. In our paper, we have a whole section on compartmentalizing Mencius if anyone is looking for more information on that:

text: Spinach has a lot of iron in it. So does Rust. (Entirely posthoc name justification!)

elements.text: Spinach has a lot of iron in it. So does Rust. (Entirely posthoc name justification!)

text: The real lineage is a different pun. I built a little lattice library last year called Arugula — because it’s a little lettuce library. Spinach is the follow-on from the smarter folks.

elements.text: The real lineage is a different pun. I built a little lattice library last year called Arugula — because it’s a little lettuce library. Spinach is the follow-on from the smarter folks.

text:
Here’s a rough attempt to summarize what we heard from Berkeley:
1. *Serverless systems can benefit greatly from coordination-freeness.* We’ve done a bunch of work exploiting what we “CALMly” know about monotonicity & coordination-freeness to build any-scale serverless systems with tunable, pretty-rich consistency. Anna is an example as a KVS, and Cloudburst offers familiar FaaS computation above it (hiding the monotonicity requirements from the programmer).
2. *Coordination protocols have coordination-freeness inside!* Even protocols like Multipaxos benefit from the embarassing parallelism and sharding of monotone computation. While they have non-monotone components, we can whittle (whittaker?) them down and scale the rest. We’re working on techniques to convert this from PhD invention to compiler optimization
3. *Faceted programming can unlock these ideas for many programming models.* By separating concerns into facets, we want to enable a broad set of programming models for distributed computing, over a broad set of system/HW configs below. Underneath this is an Intermediate Representation (IR) currently called Spinach that intends to provide a provably-monotonic programming model and high performance Rust-based runtime.

elements.text: Here’s a rough attempt to summarize what we heard from Berkeley:
Serverless systems can benefit greatly from coordination-freeness.

We’ve done a bunch of work exploiting what we “CALMly” know about monotonicity & coordination-freeness to build any-scale serverless systems with tunable, pretty-rich consistency. Anna is an example as a KVS, and Cloudburst offers familiar FaaS computation above it (hiding the monotonicity requirements from the programmer).
Coordination protocols have coordination-freeness inside!

Even protocols like Multipaxos benefit from the embarassing parallelism and sharding of monotone computation. While they have non-monotone components, we can whittle (whittaker?) them down and scale the rest. We’re working on techniques to convert this from PhD invention to compiler optimization
Faceted programming can unlock these ideas for many programming models.

By separating concerns into facets, we want to enable a broad set of programming models for distributed computing, over a broad set of system/HW configs below. Underneath this is an Intermediate Representation (IR) currently called Spinach that intends to provide a provably-monotonic programming model and high performance Rust-based runtime.
